zone.line: Chapter IX VIII
I was carried to the next town: fever
succeeded to convulsions and faintings, &
for some weeks my unhappy spirit
hovered on the very verge of death. But
life was yet strong within me; I recovered:
nor did it a lettele little aid my
returning health that my recollections
were at first vague, and that I
was too weak to feel any violent emotion.
I often said to myself, My father is dead.
He loved me with a guilty passion, and
stung by remorse and despair he killed
himself. Why is it that I feel no horror?
Are these circumstances not dreadful?
Is it not enough that I shall never
more meet the eyes of my beloved
father; never more hear his voice;
no caress, no look? All cold, and stiff, and
dead! Alas! I am quite callous: the
night I was out in was fearful and the
